author: Merry
title: Millions of obese patients taking Ozempic are at risk of gaining MORE weight – because they don’t take the drug for long enough, experts warn
text:
Few words were more on people’s lips in 2023 than Ozempic, Wegovy and Mounjaro.
Successful weight loss medications, which work by suppressing hunger hormones, are very effective.
But now, experts warn that many of the nine million prescriptions given for these drugs could be, at best, useless and, at worst, putting patients at even greater risk of suffering from drug-related illnesses. weight.
This is because many are given courses of the medication that are too short.
According to recent warnings, employers are offering insurance plans that only cover use of the drug for a short period, such as a year, to save money.
However, a growing body of evidence shows that patients who stop taking weekly injectable medications quickly regain the pounds they lost.
About 9 million Ozempic prescriptions were issued in early 2022 alone.
What’s more, abruptly stopping medications puts patients at greater risk for weight-related health problems, such as high blood pressure, high blood glucose levels, and changes in cholesterol.
The effects of abruptly stopping weight-loss medications are similar to those of harmful yo-yo dieting, which causes a cycle of weight loss and regain that contributes to the risk of type 2 diabetes, heart attacks, and eating disorders.
Brooke Boyarsky Pratt, a prescriber and CEO of the Knownwell weight loss clinic in New York, says she has seen many patients who were told they would stop taking the medication after 12 months.
“I think it will be a compelling narrative given the number of patients who qualify for these drugs and their high cost,” he told Fierce Healthcare.
“The difficulty is that there is no data to support that (weight loss after one year) and, in fact, the data very clearly suggests the opposite.”
The problem lies with healthcare companies that employers are increasingly using to get good insurance for their employees.
One of the most popular companies that does this is Calibrate, which primarily prescribes medications directly to patients.
It also works with insurance companies to get patients the drug for about $25 a month.
More recently, it has begun helping employers negotiate better, lower-cost insurance deals for workers.
As part of this, Calibrate is launching plans that provide a limited course of medications before tapering them off to patients, a way to reduce costs for the employer.
A UK study found that people who used Wegovy experienced rapid weight loss, losing 18% of their weight in 68 weeks. They regained two-thirds of that weight, or 12% of their original body weight, in the year after stopping the weekly injections. Experts say the drug should be used throughout life to avoid weight loss
The most recent anti-obesity drug to hit the market was Eli Lilly’s Zebpound, a rebranding of the pharmaceutical giant’s existing type 2 diabetes drug, Mounjaro.
Both medications contain the active ingredient tirzepatide, which suppresses two hormones that regulate appetite, making people feel fuller for longer.
Other blockbusters include Wegovy and Ozempic, the same drugs but in different doses containing semaglutide, which stimulates weight loss by mimicking the actions of GLP-1, or glucagon-like peptide-1, a hormone in the brain that regulates appetite and feeling of satiety. .
While extremely effective at helping patients lose an average of 15 to 20 percent of their body weight, the medications cost a little more than $1,300 per package, which breaks down to nearly $270 per week or about $16,190 per anus. Insurance doesn’t always pay the bill.
Calibrate specializes in working directly with consumers who pay a one-time fee of approximately $1,700 to gain access to personalized health counseling and, if eligible, a prescription for a weight loss medication for an additional cost per dose.
The company then negotiates with insurers to have patients shell out a monthly cost of $25 or less. But the company has struggled to give patients timely access to drugs amid shortages and insurers reducing coverage.
Now, Calibrate is working with employers who provide health insurance to workers and with the insurance companies themselves.
The goal is to have the Calibrate program, including the medications your doctors prescribe, covered by insurance plans that employers purchase for their employees.
Companies like Ro and Calibrate describe their weight loss programs that include medications as the most effective approach to achieving sustainable weight loss. But they fail to make it clear that most people need to continue taking medications to maintain weight.
Brooke Boyarsky Pratt, founder and CEO of weight loss clinic Knowwell, said
Fierce healthcare: ‘I think we’re going to see more and more LPG-1 companies that were previously business-to-consumer now selling into the employer space, claiming they have the silver bullet for spending LPG-1.
“We’re hearing from employers everywhere that this is what they’re being told.”
Calibrate said it has designed a program to help patients taking the drugs reduce their dosage and eventually stop taking them altogether, a benefit to insurers who would not need to cover the expensive medications indefinitely.
A Calibrate spokesperson said: “While the current clinical paradigm for GLP-1 treatment requires lifelong medication at the highest dose, Calibrate is exploring whether members can stop taking the medication while maintaining their results.”
“As a result, Calibrate is the first and only program with a proactive plan to get members off medications.”
Calibrate conducted its own analysis to see if its members could maintain weight, reporting that 93 percent suffered more than 10 percent weight loss six to 12 months after starting to taper off GLP-1 medications.
Influencer Remi Bader said she “gained back twice as much weight” after stopping taking Ozempic, which she had been prescribed to help her deal with binge eating.
The latest data showing the rebound between weight loss and gain comes from a study conducted in
JAMA, which revealed that tirzepatide, which works like Ozempic, helped patients lose about 20 percent of their body weight after 36 weeks. But when they switched to a placebo, they regained 14 percent of the weight they lost over the next 52 weeks.
The authors said: “At least five trials (including the present study) with various classes of drugs, including powerful anti-obesity drugs such as semaglutide, have shown substantial weight regain after smoking cessation.”
Studies on the effects of stopping Wegovy and Ozempic have provided similar results. A 2022 study in the journal
Diabetes, Obesity and Metabolism reported that patients taking semaglutide for 68 weeks lost an average of 17.3 percent of their body weight.
When they stopped treatment, they regained 11.6 percent of the weight lost at week 120, resulting in a net weight loss of just under six percent of body weight.
said Dr. Ania Jastreboff, an obesity medicine expert at Yale University.
People: If you have a patient who has high blood pressure, has hypertension, and you start them on an antihypertensive medication and their blood pressure improves, what would happen if you stopped that medication?
Medications like Ozempic and Wegovy are not a panacea for obesity, which experts say is a chronic disease that requires ongoing medication treatment as well as healthy lifestyle habits that include exercise and a healthy diet.
‘Well, his blood pressure would go up again, and we’re not surprised. The same goes for anti-obesity medications.’
Doctors say this is because the medications do not treat all the underlying causes of obesity, including poor lifestyle habits and a warped psychological relationship with food.
Dr Elie Jarrouge, a Houston-based metabolic disease expert, said: ‘For people taking Ozempic or Wegovy to lose weight… What is your exit strategy?
“If you don’t work to change what you eat, not just how much you eat and your relationship with food, you’re likely to gain the weight back.”
Influencer Remi Bader attested to this, having regained “double the weight” she had lost while taking Ozempic.
Bader had sought treatment for binge eating disorder, which she said got much worse when she stopped taking the medication.
She said: “I saw a doctor and they said: it’s 100% because I took Ozempic.”
‘It made me think I wasn’t hungry for so long that I lost some weight. I didn’t want to obsess over being in this for the long haul. I thought: I bet as soon as I get out I’ll starve again. I did and my binge eating got much worse. “So I blamed Ozempic.”

author: Андрей Кулик\n
title: Кнессет Израиля не поддержал законопроект о самороспуске парламента
text:
Кнессет Израиля не поддержал законопроект о самороспуске парламента
Киев • УНН
Парламент Израиля отклонил инициативу о самороспуске, правительственная коалиция достигла компромисса по законопроекту о воинской обязанности для ультраортодоксов.
Парламент Израиля в четверг утром не поддержал на голосовании инициативу о самороспуске. Это произошло после достижения компромисса в правящей коалиции по спорному законопроекту о воинской обязанности. Об этом сообщает УНН со ссылкой на Reuters.
Детали
Предварительное голосование, которое могло стать первым шагом к досрочным выборам, не набрало необходимого количества голосов: 61 депутат выступил против, 53 – поддержали. В Кнесете 120 мест, поэтому для принятия решения требовалось простое большинство.
Это решение дало правительству Биньямина Нетаньяху дополнительное время на урегулирование глубокого политического кризиса, избегая досрочных выборов, которые стали бы первыми от начала войны с ХАМАС в секторе Газа.
Премьер-министр пытается сохранить целостность коалиции, где идет конфликт вокруг законопроекта, касающегося освобождения от обязательной службы для ультраортодоксальных еврейских семинаристов.
Я рад объявить, что после длительных обсуждений мы достигли договоренностей относительно принципов, на которых будет базироваться этот законопроект
Вопрос освобождения религиозных студентов от службы давно раскалывает израильское общество, но обострился во время полномасштабной военной кампании в Газе. Армия Израиля несет самые серьезные потери за десятилетие и нуждается в новых резервистах.
На фоне этого конфликта некоторые ультраортодоксальные фракции в коалиции заявили, что готовы поддержать оппозицию в голосовании за роспуск парламента, чтобы ускорить проведение выборов, которые иначе должны состояться не раньше конца 2026 года.
Сейчас как никогда срочно нужно заменить правительство Нетаньяху, а особенно это токсичное и вредное правительство. Срочно нужно прекратить войну в Газе и вернуть всех заложников. Срочно нужно начать восстановление и исцеление государства Израиль
Дополнительно
Согласно социологическим опросам, правительственная коалиция Биньямина Нетаньяху рискует проиграть будущие выборы из-за глубокого общественного недовольства. Возмущение вызвано, в частности, неудачной защитой страны во время нападения ХАМАС 7 октября 2023 года.
Это нападение привело к самому кровавому дню в истории Израиля – погибли 1200 человек, а 251 израильтянин был захвачен в заложники. Боевые действия, которые продолжаются уже более восьми месяцев, унесли жизни более 400 израильских военных.
Справка
Ультраортодоксальные партии в Израиле настаивают на освобождении своих сторонников от армейской службы, считая религиозное обучение священным долгом. Впрочем, в контексте войны в Газе общественная поддержка таких исключений резко упала.
The New York Times: ХАМАС во время нападения 7 октября использовал израильское оружие29.01.24, 00:43 • 30176 просмотров

author: Devdiscourse News Desk
title: KPI Green Energy Inks Deal for 50MW Hybrid Project | Headlines
text: KPI Green Energy Inks Deal for 50MW Hybrid Project KPI Green Energy has signed a pact to supply power from a 50MW solar-wind hybrid project to Gujarat Urja Vikas Nigam. The project was secured through a reverse e-auction on January 22, 2024. This initiative aligns with KPI's goal to reach 1,000 MWp capacity by 2025. [Devdiscourse News Desk](/devdiscourse-stories)| New Delhi | Updated: 05-07-2024 16:28 IST | Created: 05-07-2024 16:28 IST - Country: - India KPI Green Energy has successfully inked a deal to supply power from a 50MW solar-wind hybrid project, partnering with Gujarat Urja Vikas Nigam. The project includes 50 MW solar and 16.80 MW wind components, earned through a competitive bidding process on November 1, 2023, followed by a reverse e-auction on January 22, 2024. The agreement, now formalized as a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA), propels KPI Green Energy towards its ambitious goal of achieving a 1,000 MWp capacity by 2025. This landmark deal significantly strengthens the company's renewable energy portfolio. With this successful bid, KPI Green Energy underscores its commitment to accelerating India's journey towards sustainable energy solutions. This agreement not only enhances its project footprint but also paves the way for future large-scale hybrid energy projects.

author: IT之家
title: 我国上半年充电基础设施增量达 328.2 万个，同比上升 99.2%|新能源汽车|电动汽车_新浪科技_新浪网
text:
IT之家 7 月 31 日消息，据央视新闻报道，记者今天（31 日）从中国电动汽车充电基础设施促进联盟获悉， 今年 1—6 月份，我国充电基础设施增量同比上升近一倍。
最新数据显示，2025 年 1—6 月， 充电基础设施增量为 328.2 万个，同比上升 99.2%。 其中公共充电设施增量为 51.7 万个，同比增长 30.6%，私人充电设施增量为 276.5 万个，同比上升 120.8%。
报道称，今年上半年，新能源汽车国内销量 587.8 万辆，充电基础设施与新能源汽车继续快速增长。桩车增量比为 1:1.8，充电基础设施建设能够基本满足新能源汽车的快速发展。
IT之家从报道获悉，截至 2025 年 6 月底， 我国电动汽车充电基础设施（枪）总数达到 1610.0 万个 ，同比增长 55.6%。
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->energy and resource

author: AFP
title: Richardson edges Alfred in Zurich 100m to avenge Olympic result
text:
World champion Sha'Carri Richardson went some way to avenging her Olympic defeat by Julien Alfred by reversing the tables in the 100m at the Diamond League meet in Zurich on Thursday.
Richardson headed into the final 20 metres at the Letzigrund Stadium in third behind Saint Lucia's Olympic champion Alfred and Britain's Dina Asher-Smith.
But the American stayed strong and focused on the line, producing a savage dip for first place in 10.84 seconds, 0.04sec ahead of Alfred.
"I am training and executing because I know the race is not going to take care of itself," said Richardson.
Asher-Smith, who failed to make the 100m final in the French capital, rounded out the podium in 10.89sec.
Alfred had no complaints about the result, saying the race "felt good".
"I am just having fun. I am trying to finish strong. I really have not had the chance to take my medal in," she said.
"After Paris I went back to Texas, did some training. It has been up and down, I am still working on the fine tuning."
Alfred's gold in Paris was the first-ever Olympic medal of any colour for her tiny Caribbean island homeland.
And she said she was now looking to the Diamond League finls in Brussels next week and then returning home for some proper celebrations.
"In Brussels I will not run the double, just the 100m," she said.
"My aim is nothing in particular, just to finish strong. I am looking forward to go to Saint Lucia, just to celebrate with my country."
lp/jc/ea
